title: Modal collapse
summary: In modal logic, modal collapse is the condition in which every true statement is necessarily true, and vice versa; that is to say, there are no contingent truths, or to put it another way, that "everything exists necessarily".[1][2] In the notation of modal logic, this can be written as ϕ ↔ ◻ ϕ {\displaystyle \phi \leftrightarrow \Box \phi } .
